messages.text:
<@U03JNR9A2GZ> asked
> Is it possible to have hierarchical sharing for NSPersistentCloudKitContainer in iOS 16? iOS 15 only support zone sharing.

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"Is it possible to have hierarchical sharing for NSPersistentCloudKitContainer in iOS 16? iOS 15 only support zone sharing."}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: No. Hierarchical sharing is too limited for the purposes of NSPersistentCloudKitContainer.

elements.text: No. Hierarchical sharing is too limited for the purposes of NSPersistentCloudKitContainer.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Why would you want hierarchical shares as opposed to simply storing a graph of managed objects that represent your hierarchy in a zone?

elements.text: Why would you want hierarchical shares as opposed to simply storing a graph of managed objects that represent your hierarchy in a zone?

slackdump_thread_replies.text: I have an app that has a similar structure as Notes. You can have Groups and Lists within the Groups. From what I understand, I can't share a single List without sharing the entire Group and other lists within the Group.

elements.text: I have an app that has a similar structure as Notes. You can have Groups and Lists within the Groups. From what I understand, I can't share a single List without sharing the entire Group and other lists within the Group.

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
Users may want to share a single List with others without having to put it into a specific shared Group.

I hope that is making sense :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text:
Users may want to share a single List with others without having to put it into a specific shared Group.

I hope that is making sense

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Hierarchical sharing would allow users to share a single List regardless of it's parent

elements.text: Hierarchical sharing would allow users to share a single List regardless of it's parent

slackdump_thread_replies.text: That’s not entirely true. You could allow the user to nominate the list and group to share, and then break them apart such that they exist in separate logical hierarchies

elements.text: That’s not entirely true. You could allow the user to nominate the list and group to share, and then break them apart such that they exist in separate logical hierarchies

slackdump_thread_replies.text: With sharing we often have to break our notion of normalization due to different collections of actors (users) operating on some portion of a graph like this.

elements.text: With sharing we often have to break our notion of normalization due to different collections of actors (users) operating on some portion of a graph like this.

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
You end up with:

Private:
• GroupA
    ◦ List1
    ◦ List2
    ◦ List3
Shared:
• GroupA
    ◦ List4
    ◦ List5

>  Oh interesting, I wasn’t thinking I could separate the UI in that way.
I think an NSFetchedResultsController would work with a sectionNameKeyPath of “group” if your list entity identifies its group as a string property, as opposed to a to-one-relationship to a group object.

That way List objects from both stores will show up in the same section of the FRC.

messages.text:
<@U03JCC3UM6G> asked
> Using CoreData with CloudKit. Is it now possible to use constraints with NSPersistentCloudKitContainer?
> If not, what is the recommended way when importing a large amount of records?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"Using CoreData with CloudKit. Is it now possible to use constraints with NSPersistentCloudKitContainer?\nIf not, what is the recommended way when importing a large amount of records?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: You should use history tracking to traverse the changes and move them between stores as efficiently as your use case desires.

elements.text: You should use history tracking to traverse the changes and move them between stores as efficiently as your use case desires.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: so one local store with constraints and one store set up with CloudKit?

elements.text: so one local store with constraints and one store set up with CloudKit?

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Yeah, one store that contains your “desired” schema / constraints, and a Cloud store that syncs objects.

elements.text: Yeah, one store that contains your “desired” schema / constraints, and a Cloud store that syncs objects.

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
How do I merge the changes from one store to the other?
I have one entity set up with the needed attributes and a constraints for importing data. All added to the local configuration.
Do I now need to add a copy of this entity without the constraints in another configuration which works with CloudKit?

elements.text:
How do I merge the changes from one store to the other?
I have one entity set up with the needed attributes and a constraints for importing data. All added to the local configuration.
Do I now need to add a copy of this entity without the constraints in another configuration which works with CloudKit?

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Maybe?
Everyone kind of chooses their own adventure. Sometimes the schemas are different enough that they are different entities. Sometimes they are identical, but one has stricter validation requirements.

elements.text: Everyone kind of chooses their own adventure. Sometimes the schemas are different enough that they are different entities. Sometimes they are identical, but one has stricter validation requirements.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: oh wait. So when importing to the store with constraints, the history tracking will tell me only the items which actually changed? And this is the list I need to loop over to then forward these changes to the CloudKit connected store?

elements.text: oh wait. So when importing to the store with constraints, the history tracking will tell me only the items which actually changed? And this is the list I need to loop over to then forward these changes to the CloudKit connected store?

messages.text:
<@U03JEL0155X> asked
> I am using an NSPersistentCloudKitContainer to sync private stores. I added a large amount of records on device A and then successfully synced on device B. At some point, I uninstalled the app on B and reinstalled it only to find that most of my data was removed from the store.
> 
> Can a new installation inadvertently delete my data? Almost as if the new install told CloudKit "I have nothing" and CloudKit tried to delete things to make it match?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"I am using an NSPersistentCloudKitContainer to sync private stores. I added a large amount of records on device A and then successfully synced on device B. At some point, I uninstalled the app on B and reinstalled it only to find that most of my data was removed from the store.\n\nCan a new installation inadvertently delete my data? Almost as if the new install told CloudKit \"I have nothing\" and CloudKit tried to delete things to make it match?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Uninstalling the app deletes the local store files. Your data will need to download again and this process can take some time.

elements.text: Uninstalling the app deletes the local store files. Your data will need to download again and this process can take some time.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: NSPersistentCloudKitContainer does not delete data unless you tell it to.

elements.text: NSPersistentCloudKitContainer does not delete data unless you tell it to.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: That is my understanding as well. On device A, I parsed a CSV to create NSManagedObjects and CloudKit showed all ~50k records. Then at some point they were deleted and only ~9k remain. No where in my code did I explicitly delete a record. I've only un/reinstalled. :disappointed:

elements.text: That is my understanding as well. On device A, I parsed a CSV to create NSManagedObjects and CloudKit showed all ~50k records. Then at some point they were deleted and only ~9k remain. No where in my code did I explicitly delete a record. I've only un/reinstalled.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: I mean… did they ever finish uploading from DeviceA?

elements.text: I mean… did they ever finish uploading from DeviceA?

slackdump_thread_replies.text: I believe so. A few times between uploading and reinstalling I had queried CloudKit directly to get the count and it was correct.

elements.text: I believe so. A few times between uploading and reinstalling I had queried CloudKit directly to get the count and it was correct.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: It’s worth a feedback report if you have an uninstall / reinstall scenario that leads to data loss.

elements.text: It’s worth a feedback report if you have an uninstall / reinstall scenario that leads to data loss.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: But we aren’t aware of any today.

elements.text: But we aren’t aware of any today.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: We would want logs from the devices through the process I suspect.

elements.text: We would want logs from the devices through the process I suspect.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: and store files if you can provide them.

elements.text: and store files if you can provide them.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Checking the CloudKit server for the number of records is right, if the count is changing something is telling us to perform operations.

elements.text: Checking the CloudKit server for the number of records is right, if the count is changing something is telling us to perform operations.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Okay, I'll put that together and make a feedback report. Thanks.

elements.text: Okay, I'll put that together and make a feedback report. Thanks.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Uninstalled before finishing upload, or stuck before finishing download are both plausible.

elements.text: Uninstalled before finishing upload, or stuck before finishing download are both plausible.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: What could cause it to get in a stuck state?

elements.text: What could cause it to get in a stuck state?

slackdump_thread_replies.text: It’s not possible to say without logs. We could offer baseless conjecture but that’s not productive.

elements.text: It’s not possible to say without logs. We could offer baseless conjecture but that’s not productive.

Something like a "v1"/"v2" could work if it's strictly a version bump of some sort, or some sort of semantic name might also make sense, e.g. "name" and "encryptedName"

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Example, v1 of the app, we store GPS coords in a single string, later in v2 we split them into different columns

slackdump_thread_replies.text: You can't rename existing field once they've deployed into production, so you are free to name the new fields in whatever scheme is most maintainable for your developers. Using `location` and `location_v2` is definitely plausible as is `location-latitude` and `location-longitude`. Just be sure you continue populating the original field if you are maintaining compatibility with older versions of your application.

messages.text:
<@U03HVDF8N6A> asked
> What is the best way to download a default table, edit locally and sync between devices? After download the default, the user only keeps sync for himself. Not needing to upload to Public.
> I’ve been using Public to create a default DB and when downloaded, using CD to keep sync between devices. Is this right?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"What is the best way to download a default table, edit locally and sync between devices? After download the default, the user only keeps sync for himself. Not needing to upload to Public.\nI\u2019ve been using Public to create a default DB and when downloaded, using CD to keep sync between devices. Is this right?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
This is typical of a process we call “seeding.”

Clients of NSPersistentCloudKitContainer will download data from the public database to a local sqlite file, and then

1. copy relevant portions of that for user-specific customization
2. Reference it via a foreign key relationship from user-specific stores
Techniques vary, opting for 2 is the most efficient, but 1 offers better sync freshness because the private database is able to sync at a higher rate (via push notifications) than the public database.

<@U03JM8PFK2P> asked
> Can we manually force/request a sync operation of local Core Data from CloudKit when using NSPersistentCloudKitContainer?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"Can we manually force\/request a sync operation of local Core Data from CloudKit when using NSPersistentCloudKitContainer?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: No.

work is scheduled based on a number of criteria, but there is no manual sync option. If you have feedback regarding sync quality or freshness you can file a feedback report with a sysdiagnose so we can investigate.

elements.text: work is scheduled based on a number of criteria, but there is no manual sync option. If you have feedback regarding sync quality or freshness you can file a feedback report with a sysdiagnose so we can investigate.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Thanks. I was commenting in the previous question workflow. Will report back on sync quality. Specifically, how long it takes to sync public database changes when an app is lunched by a user. I understand that a sync of public database does not happen very often. However, an amount of time from a launch to sync is quite important for an overall user experience. Thanks!

elements.text: Thanks. I was commenting in the previous question workflow. Will report back on sync quality. Specifically, how long it takes to sync public database changes when an app is lunched by a user. I understand that a sync of public database does not happen very often. However, an amount of time from a launch to sync is quite important for an overall user experience. Thanks!

slackdump_thread_replies.text: The public database has a much lower expectation of sync freshness. An initial import will be performed immediately for empty store files. However subsequent imports will occur approximately once a day .

elements.text: The public database has a much lower expectation of sync freshness. An initial import will be performed immediately for empty store files. However subsequent imports will occur approximately once a day .

messages.text:
Hi everyone, and welcome to the *<https://developer.apple.com/wwdc22/10116/|Meet CKTool JS>* watch party! We’re so happy to have you all here. My name is Patrick and I’m the System Frameworks Evangelist at Apple! In this hour, we’re inviting you to watch *<https://developer.apple.com/wwdc22/10116/|Meet CKTool JS>* together, alongside our presenter Kent Wong! Queue up the video and get ready to *hit play at 2:05pm PDT*. In addition to Kent, we’re also joined by the CloudKit team who are ready to answer your questions!

There’s a lot of us here, so we’re going to do our best to keep things organized. As the video progresses, I’ll be creating threads associated with each section of the talk, where everyone can chat and ask questions (don’t watch at 2x speed — don’t sync with your video-container too quick!)

We’ll get started at *2:05pm PDT* sharp! Hit the play button with us at the same time to stay in sync!

When the video finishes, we’ll have some time left over for additional targeted Q&A, which I’ll explain when we get there. So for the next few minutes, grab your popcorn, get comfortable, and get ready to hit that play button in 5 min!

messages.text: :thread: A lot of questions we get revolve around Zone sharing — let’s ask some experts!

slackdump_thread_replies.text: What are some of the benefits of a zone share over a hierarchical share? Any advice you can give us <@U03JMJN8Q6A>?

elements.text: What are some of the benefits of a zone share over a hierarchical share? Any advice you can give us

slackdump_thread_replies.text: If your data is naturally hierarchical (e.g. a filesystem of folders and files), a hierarchical share is the most natural way to express that data. It's possible to express something like this with zone sharing, but you may have to do a lot of gymnastics to support moving records between different hierarchies (e.g. when the user moves a file to a different folder)

elements.text: If your data is naturally hierarchical (e.g. a filesystem of folders and files), a hierarchical share is the most natural way to express that data. It's possible to express something like this with zone sharing, but you may have to do a lot of gymnastics to support moving records between different hierarchies (e.g. when the user moves a file to a different folder)

slackdump_thread_replies.text: If your data is more flat or amorphous, then a zone share can make sharing much easier since all you have to do is put the records in that zone

elements.text: If your data is more flat or amorphous, then a zone share can make sharing much easier since all you have to do is put the records in that zone

slackdump_thread_replies.text: +1 tim! Zones are an excellent way of logically organizing data, so if you’re already leveraging the power of zones, zone sharing can easily add powerful new features to your app. We have a tech-talk covering CloudKit Sharing that delves into zone sharing available <https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/tech-talks/10874/|here> if you’d like to learn more.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Zone sharing also maps more closely to the fundamentals of how CloudKit sync works. A `CKServerChangeToken`  maps to a single zone. If you have multiple hierarchical shares in a zone, then you can't sync each one individually. You have to sync the entire zone. If you can separate your shares into multiple zones, then you can potentially have more control over what syncs and when

messages.text:
<@U03J207J01G> asked
> If User A shared record LogRecord(CKRecord) with User B. Any way to get remote notification for User B when Record A is modified by User A?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"If User A shared record LogRecord(CKRecord) with User B. Any way to get remote notification for User B when Record A is modified by User A?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: This sounds like a good use-case for <https://developer.apple.com/documentation/cloudkit/ckdatabasesubscription|CKDatabaseSubscription>. You can subscribe to notifications on User B’s shared database, so when User A modifies that shared record, User B will receive a notification that there is a change to their shared database. You’d then need to handle that notification and fetch the latest from the shared database. There are additional useful docs on the `CKSubscription` class <https://developer.apple.com/documentation/cloudkit/cksubscription|here>.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: I would like to have `CKQuerySubscription` also available for shared databases. In this case, User A can set up a query subscription for their private database. If user B modifies the record, A gets notified about the specific changed record. However, for user B, only `CKDatabaseSubscription` is available, they get notified "something changed" which isn’t really appropriate for e.g directly displaying to user as push notification.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: You can monitor sync progress via <https://developer.apple.com/documentation/coredata/nspersistentcloudkitcontainer/event|NSPersistentCloudKitContainer.Event> on both the export and import side which can be used to provide feedback to your users on the state of the sync. Do note, there will always be a propagation delay between the time Device A saves some changes and Device B is aware changes were made, this is the nature of network distributed systems.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: For anyone reading this who might be using CloudKit directly (<@U03J1V9TNLT> I see your :eyes:, although maybe you're using NSPersistentCloudKitContainer too), you can specify `desiredKeys` when fetching your records. You'd exclude any keys that contain `CKAssets`. Then, when the user performs some action that requires the asset, you'd fetch the record with that asset key in the `desiredKeys` to finally fetch the asset file

Hi Brady :wave:

The error you’re seeing can happen when you haven’t set up indexes for your recordType in the Console.

Could you please try the following:
1. Navigate to *Indexes* under the *Schema* heading in the sidebar
2. Select the recordType that you want to make queries against
3. Click “Add Basic Index”
4. In the “Field” dropdown select “recordName”
5. In the “Index Type” select “queryable”
6. Press “Save Changes”

messages.text:
<@U03J20XDZ3L> asked
> I recently had a user accidentally delete my app (data) from his iCloud account. Is there a way he could have restored his data? Either via a UI or via Apple Support?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"I recently had a user accidentally delete my app (data) from his iCloud account. Is there a way he could have restored his data? Either via a UI or via Apple Support?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Did they delete the data via the Manage Storage API in Settings? Or via your app?

elements.text: Did they delete the data via the Manage Storage API in Settings? Or via your app?

slackdump_thread_replies.text: In general, if you delete data from CloudKit, it will be gone forever

elements.text: In general, if you delete data from CloudKit, it will be gone forever

slackdump_thread_replies.text: This is both a good thing (we don't keep data that the user thinks is deleted) and a bad thing (the user might lose data like this)

elements.text: This is both a good thing (we don't keep data that the user thinks is deleted) and a bad thing (the user might lose data like this)

slackdump_thread_replies.text: One thing that some apps do is to introduce the concept of "Recently Deleted" data that can be recovered

elements.text: One thing that some apps do is to introduce the concept of "Recently Deleted" data that can be recovered

slackdump_thread_replies.text: That would just be normal data in the database, but shown in a different place in the UI (for example the Recently Deleted folder in Notes)

elements.text: That would just be normal data in the database, but shown in a different place in the UI (for example the Recently Deleted folder in Notes)

slackdump_thread_replies.text: You could even keep user-deleted data around in your database temporarily, but with a flag that hides it from the UI. Then at some point you clean it up (e.g. after 30 days or something)

elements.text: You could even keep user-deleted data around in your database temporarily, but with a flag that hides it from the UI. Then at some point you clean it up (e.g. after 30 days or something)

slackdump_thread_replies.text: But sadly for this particular user, if the data is deleted from CloudKit, it's unrecoverable

elements.text: But sadly for this particular user, if the data is deleted from CloudKit, it's unrecoverable

messages.text:
<@U03HVE4TV8E> asked
> Hello! When releasing an update with updates to the CloudKit Cloud Schema, should you publish changes to production before App Review or after it releases on the App Store? Thanks :grin:

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"Hello! When releasing an update with updates to the CloudKit Cloud Schema, should you publish changes to production before App Review or after it releases on the App Store? Thanks "},{"type":"emoji","name":"grin"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: The best practice here is to promote schema changes before submitting an app for review. The App Review team would be looking for a full app experience which I assume includes using the latest schema for your app.

elements.text: The best practice here is to promote schema changes before submitting an app for review. The App Review team would be looking for a full app experience which I assume includes using the latest schema for your app.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Great, thank you so much! :grin::ok_hand:
I’d also add Testflight. Before submitting, it’s a good idea to test with Testflight testers. TF builds work against the public schema.

elements.text: I’d also add Testflight. Before submitting, it’s a good idea to test with Testflight testers. TF builds work against the public schema.

messages.text:
<@U03JDV4PQR0> asked
> With NSPersistentStoreRemoteChange is there a way to filter out local changes from remote? There are times I only want to react to remote changes.

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"With NSPersistentStoreRemoteChange is there a way to filter out local changes from remote? There are times I only want to react to remote changes."}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: When you say 'remote', do you mean another device or another process on the same device?

elements.text: When you say 'remote', do you mean another device or another process on the same device?

slackdump_thread_replies.text: I want to ignore everything on the current device and only react to changes from other devices.

elements.text: I want to ignore everything on the current device and only react to changes from other devices.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Great, take a look at <https://developer.apple.com/documentation/coredata/nspersistentstoreremotechangenotification|NSPersistentStoreRemoteChangeNotification> and let us know if you have any questions

elements.text: and let us know if you have any questions

slackdump_thread_replies.text: That’s not what NSPersistentStoreRemoteChangeNotification does. NSPersistentStoreRemoteChangeNotification only informs you that the store file has changed, not that changes were imported from CloudKit. NSPersistentCloudKitContainerEvent fills that role.

elements.text: That’s not what NSPersistentStoreRemoteChangeNotification does. NSPersistentStoreRemoteChangeNotification only informs you that the store file has changed, not that changes were imported from CloudKit. NSPersistentCloudKitContainerEvent fills that role.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Thank you!

messages.text:
<@U03JHD6Q60H> asked
> Hey there. I have two questions about CloudKit sharing.
> 
> 1. If User A shares e.g. a Record with User B who has the app not installed, is iOS giving them a prompt to download the app or does the user has to do that by hand?
> 2. If I have a main app and in addition to that a second app (e.g. a companion app), is there a possibility to share a record from the main app to the companion app? And if so, can I somehow specify the app I want to share the record with? 
> 
> Thanks a lot for the info in advance!

elements.Raw:
{"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"Hey there. I have two questions about CloudKit sharing.

1. If User A shares e.g. a Record with User B who has the app not installed, is iOS giving them a prompt to download the app or does the user has to do that by hand?
2. If I have a main app and in addition to that a second app (e.g. a companion app), is there a possibility to share a record from the main app to the companion app? And if so, can I somehow specify the app I want to share the record with? 

Thanks a lot for the info in advance!"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: If a user taps on a CloudKit sharing link, but they don't have the app installed, the system will prompt them to open the App Store and install the app

elements.text: If a user taps on a CloudKit sharing link, but they don't have the app installed, the system will prompt them to open the App Store and install the app

slackdump_thread_replies.text: As for the companion app, CloudKit sharing is tied to the CloudKit container, not the app itself. So as long as the second app also has access to the CloudKit container, it can share data with the main app

elements.text: As for the companion app, CloudKit sharing is tied to the CloudKit container, not the app itself. So as long as the second app also has access to the CloudKit container, it can share data with the main app

slackdump_thread_replies.text: You wouldn't be able to specify which app to share the record with, but if the user has both apps installed, they'll be able to choose which app to open the share link

elements.text: You wouldn't be able to specify which app to share the record with, but if the user has both apps installed, they'll be able to choose which app to open the share link

slackdump_thread_replies.text: If they only have one of the two apps installed, then it'll open in the installed app

elements.text: If they only have one of the two apps installed, then it'll open in the installed app

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Thanks. If no app of the both is installed, probably the prompt asks to install the app from wich the sharing was initiated?

elements.text: Thanks. If no app of the both is installed, probably the prompt asks to install the app from wich the sharing was initiated?

slackdump_thread_replies.text: If neither app is installed, we'll prompt to install one or the other, but no guarantees on which one

elements.text: If neither app is installed, we'll prompt to install one or the other, but no guarantees on which one

slackdump_thread_replies.text: I don't believe we store the app that actually initiated the share, so we can't necessarily choose which one, although that's worth a feature request via Feedback Assistant

elements.text: I don't believe we store the app that actually initiated the share, so we can't necessarily choose which one, although that's worth a feature request via Feedback Assistant

slackdump_thread_replies.text: If the data is changing, I may suggest having a single  versioned asset file (instead of many records) uploaded to PublicDB. For upload and management, you could potentially use the CloudKit Console.

elements.text: If the data is changing, I may suggest having a single  versioned asset file (instead of many records) uploaded to PublicDB. For upload and management, you could potentially use the CloudKit Console.

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
1. to reduce app size
2. being in the public db there is no need to bundle it with each app as its “global”
3. being able to update regualrly without app review

slackdump_thread_replies.text: And I’ll be honest, I haven’t touched it in recent months. But for a former client, we wanted to prepolulate the public DB and ebing flexible on date and bulk up-/download was essential.

elements.text: And I’ll be honest, I haven’t touched it in recent months. But for a former client, we wanted to prepolulate the public DB and ebing flexible on date and bulk up-/download was essential.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: All I could figure out was to develop a companion app and up/download iteratively but it was super weak and slowwww….

elements.text: All I could figure out was to develop a companion app and up/download iteratively but it was super weak and slowwww….

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Uploads depend on number of records and assets and their size + network conditions. Also, that might impact first UX. That's why I suggested using a single file with the "compressed" records and assets.

elements.text: Uploads depend on number of records and assets and their size + network conditions. Also, that might impact first UX. That's why I suggested using a single file with the "compressed" records and assets.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Indeed for 1st launch experience, we have the most recent “copy” inside of the app (and for supporting offline-1st-approach).

elements.text: Indeed for 1st launch experience, we have the most recent “copy” inside of the app (and for supporting offline-1st-approach).

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Still the question holds: can we bulk up/download to CloudKit somehow relaibly and fast?

messages.text:
<@U03J20E1BPD> asked
> In WWDC21, NSPersistentCloudKitContainer added support for sharing between different users. What is the expected sync delay? Is it possible to add SharePlay on top of that to reduce the delay?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"In WWDC21, NSPersistentCloudKitContainer added support for sharing between different users. What is the expected sync delay? Is it possible to add SharePlay on top of that to reduce the delay?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: In most cases the sync will take a delay in seconds order of magnitude. The delay depends on a number of conditions, such as number of records, file size, network conditions, etc.  Share Play does not take a role in how NSPersistentCloudKitContainer shares data between users.

elements.text: In most cases the sync will take a delay in seconds order of magnitude. The delay depends on a number of conditions, such as number of records, file size, network conditions, etc.  Share Play does not take a role in how NSPersistentCloudKitContainer shares data between users.

messages.text:
<@U03JBGPGQCF> asked
> Hey everyone! What would be best practice to start and end sync with NSPersistentCloudKitContainer at runtime? So a user could toggle sync.
> I'm thinking of removing all stores and re-loading them setting the cloudKitContainerOptions appropriately. 
> Anything else I need to do? Like resetting the context?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"Hey everyone! What would be best practice to start and end sync with NSPersistentCloudKitContainer at runtime? So a user could toggle sync.\nI'm thinking of removing all stores and re-loading them setting the cloudKitContainerOptions appropriately. \nAnything else I need to do? Like resetting the context?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: We do not recommend attempting to manually control sync state in this way. Users control the ability of your application to sync using the application’s switch in Settings.

elements.text: We do not recommend attempting to manually control sync state in this way. Users control the ability of your application to sync using the application’s switch in Settings.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Removing the cloudKitContainerOptions from a store, and then reusing that store file creates a number of privacy and identity issues that NSPersistentCloudKitContainer cannot recover from if the user changes the iCloud account on their device.

elements.text: Removing the cloudKitContainerOptions from a store, and then reusing that store file creates a number of privacy and identity issues that NSPersistentCloudKitContainer cannot recover from if the user changes the iCloud account on their device.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Understood. So is it ok to just start sync without asking the user since they are signed into iCloud? I'm dealing with sensitive data and want to give users a choice to start sync.

elements.text: Understood. So is it ok to just start sync without asking the user since they are signed into iCloud? I'm dealing with sensitive data and want to give users a choice to start sync.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: We would advise that you use a separate store file for that.

elements.text: We would advise that you use a separate store file for that.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: i.e. one store file that’s always local, never synced.

elements.text: i.e. one store file that’s always local, never synced.

messages.text:
<@U03JM8PFK2P> asked
> I have several thousands records in a public CloudKit database. The records are added daily and there is only a handful of new records every day. The new records are added by one central process outside of the actual iOS app. All app users need read only access to all the records.
> The iOS app is using NSPersistentCloudKitContainer to sync the Core Data store with the public CloudKit database.
> After watching the WWDC20 'Sync a Core Data store with the CloudKit public database' video I thought this sync methodology would work perfectly in the above scenario. Here is a quote from the presentation.
> "So we're only going to poll for changes on application launch or after about every 30 minutes of application use. And this is to ensure that we align the load of these requests with the actual usage of your applications. Of course, this does mean that the quality of freshness that you can expect from the public database will be noticeably different from the private database."
> In practice I encountered two issues:
> 1. The initial import of the records happens in batches. This is understandable since it balances the load on the CloudKit servers. However, the way the records are imported is not ideal. I had records created everyday from September to May. When the import process started users saw records from March appear in the app first. The other records were imported later. This was not ideal. I would like to have control on which records are imported first. In my scenario I would like the newest records to appear first in the application. This way users would not be confused why there are only old records visible in the app. It is much easier to explain to users that it takes time to import and that the older records are imported later, when the newest records are visible first.
> 
> 2. From the above quote "poll for changes on application launch" - the poll for changes should ideally happen when application comes back to the foreground. Of course if the poll can be done only every 30 minutes, then it should be throttled accordingly. My point is that the moment when a user opens the app and looks at the data, the moment when the application comes back to the foreground, is critical from the user experience point of view and you want the data to be up to date as much as possible at this particular moment. Perhaps the app should be able to signal and ask for poll to be performed and the system would perform the poll for changes if other time related criteria are met?

elements.Raw:
{"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"I have several thousands records in a public CloudKit database. The records are added daily and there is only a handful of new records every day. The new records are added by one central process outside of the actual iOS app. All app users need read only access to all the records.
The iOS app is using NSPersistentCloudKitContainer to sync the Core Data store with the public CloudKit database.
After watching the WWDC20 'Sync a Core Data store with the CloudKit public database' video I thought this sync methodology would work perfectly in the above scenario. Here is a quote from the presentation.
"So we're only going to poll for changes on application launch or after about every 30 minutes of application use. And this is to ensure that we align the load of these requests with the actual usage of your applications. Of course, this does mean that the quality of freshness that you can expect from the public database will be noticeably different from the private database."
In practice I encountered two issues:
1. The initial import of the records happens in batches. This is understandable since it balances the load on the CloudKit servers. However, the way the records are imported is not ideal. I had records created everyday from September to May. When the import process started users saw records from March appear in the app first. The other records were imported later. This was not ideal. I would like to have control on which records are imported first. In my scenario I would like the newest records to appear first in the application. This way users would not be confused why there are only old records visible in the app. It is much easier to explain to users that it takes time to import and that the older records are imported later, when the newest records are visible first.

2. From the above quote "poll for changes on application launch" - the poll for changes should ideally happen when application comes back to the foreground. Of course if the poll can be done only every 30 minutes, then it should be throttled accordingly. My point is that the moment when a user opens the app and looks at the data, the moment when the application comes back to the foreground, is critical from the user experience point of view and you want the data to be up to date as much as possible at this particular moment. Perhaps the app should be able to signal and ask for poll to be performed and the system would perform the poll for changes if other time related criteria are met?"}]}
